awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: A Stacked Plasmonic Nanopore for Tether-Free Stretching and Label-Free Sensing of hSTf Dynamics and Complex Formation at Ultra-Low Concentrations
awd_abstract_narration:
Fundamental knowledge of protein structures and their dynamic responses to stimuli or other molecules is important for many applications, including medical diagnosis and therapy.  This research aims to develop a highly sensitive approach for studying the human serum transferrin protein (hSTf), which is a vital iron carrier in blood and of clinical importance.  The sensing technique would allow differentiation of the free hSTf protein from the iron-bound protein and evaluation of iron deficiency or iron overload from very small blood samples.  Successful development of this sensor would also enable profiling of a wide range of other proteins and biological molecules, e.g., DNA.  This project offers excellent opportunities for interdisciplinary research training as it combines biochemistry, nanoengineering, photonics, and electrical engineering.  The outreach efforts to K-12 schools through various programs at the Southern Methodist University and  the University of Texas at Arlington help to inspire more students to pursue science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) degrees.

The stacked plasmonic nanosensor is based on the self-induced back-action (SIBA) actuated nanopore electrophoresis (SANE) sensing concept.  The stacked nanopores are uniquely designed to enable 1) controlled trapping, releasing, and recapturing of proteins or the substrate-bound protein complexes, 2) transient deformation of the biological molecules, which can be induced by thermal effect or a combination of optical and electrical techniques, and 3) study of their deformation dynamics.  The SANE concept implemented in the stacked nanopore sensor allows investigation of protein interactions at concentrations 1000-fold below the equilibrium dissociation constant in bulk solution, making this technique ultra-sensitive.  An important aim of this research is the study of the properties of free-hSTf protein and the iron-bound protein complex using the SANE sensor.  Optical signature profiles are established for each of the species to enable selective admission of bound complexes over unbound proteins in a mixed solution to the underlying pore. It uses symmetric (VCapture = VRecapture), followed by asymmetric (VCapture ≠ VRecapture) voltage conditions to facilitate the investigation of the strength and kinetic parameters associated with protein-substrate binding, protein relaxation times, and whether voltage-induced protein unfolding is reversible or not.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit: It is of clinical value to be able to verify that our body is maintaining iron concentration in the blodd at stable levels. A protein called hSTf is considered as one of the most important proteins fpr transporting iron in the blood. Our technology will distinguish between different hSTf iron-carrying species by enabling novel types of label-free (no additional chemicals), single-molecule measurements of the hSTf protein.  Specifically, we measure how this protein gets unfoldded from a bundle-like structure into a chain like tructure by our sensor. We also measure how this protein binds to its receptor on cells that then trasport iron inside cells. Our ultra-high sensitivity sensor allows researchers to quantify the fraction of hSTf protein in the blood that is loaded with iron, and therefore helps detect iron deficiency or iron overload, from very small blood samples. In addition this project has a number of scientific merits: (1) to optically trap and electrically recapture free protein and protein-receptor complexes to enable measuring their interactions one by one, (2) enable study of single hSTf protein unfolding and refolding dynamics induced by voltage and optical gradients, transient optical heating and changes in pH, and (3) enable estimating binding strength, association and dissociation rates of single portein-receptor complexes as a function of temperature and pH. Importantly, now that we have demostrated proof of principle, this platform can be readily extended to study other proteins of clinical value for other pathological conditions.

Broader Impact: Characterizing cliically importnat proteins from blodd samples through nanopore-based techniques is becoming widely popular both in academia and in many startup compnaies. Therefore we believe thst this porject has helped prepare all involved undergraduate and graduate students for the next step in their careers. Furthermore, this project had inextricable links between biochemistry, nanoengineering, photonics, and resistive pulse sensing which would be beneficial to encourage more students to pursue STEM degrees through our outreach programs. At SMU, the INSPIRE academy has brought cutting edge nanofabrication and nanometrology to high school teachers and students. At UTA, the College of Engineering has brought our research to life for K-12 schools visiting our labs as part of local scholl distric educational inititives that we particpate in. The PIs also made strong efforts to utilize web-based and social media outlets such as YouTube to feature our scientific discoveries and make science more appealing to K-12 students, teachers and the general public.
